content: How can I help you today?
I'm not sure, honestly. My wife pushed me to come here, but I’m not convinced this is going to help. Things have just been really hard at home, and I don’t even know where to start.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like things have been challenging lately, and you might be feeling unsure about what this session could do for you. Would you like to talk a bit more about what’s been going on at home? We can start wherever feels comfortable for you.

Yeah, I guess the main thing is my son. He’s been acting out a lot, and no matter what my wife and I try, we just can’t seem to help him. It’s putting so much strain on everything—our marriage, my focus at work, even my ability to enjoy anything. It’s overwhelming, to be honest.

That sounds really overwhelming, juggling all of those struggles and feeling like you're trying everything without making progress. It seems like you really care about your family and want things to get better for your son, but the weight of all this is taking a toll on different parts of your life. What has it been like for you to handle all of this pressure?

It’s just been exhausting. I feel like I can’t catch a break—between my son’s behavior, the tension with my wife, and just trying to keep it together at work, it feels like too much. I don’t even have the energy to enjoy time with my daughter or do anything for myself anymore. It’s like... I’m failing at everything at once.

That sounds incredibly draining, like you’re being pulled in so many directions without the space to recharge or focus on the things that usually bring joy. It’s clear you deeply care about your family and your responsibilities, but feeling spread thin like that can really weigh heavy. What do you think has been the hardest part of all this for you?

Honestly, it’s feeling like I’m letting everyone down, especially my son and my wife. No matter what I do, it doesn’t seem to be enough, and that sense of failure just keeps piling up. I want to fix things, but I don’t even know where to start anymore.

It sounds like you’re holding a lot of responsibility on your shoulders, and feeling like you’re not doing enough—even though it’s clear you’re putting in so much effort. That desire to fix things comes from how much you care about your family and their happiness, but it seems like you're also feeling lost about what to do next. How do you typically cope when things feel this heavy?
Honestly, I don’t know if I’m even coping right now. I just try to push through and keep everything going, but it’s like I’m running on empty. Most days, I feel like I’m just barely getting by.

It sounds like you’ve been doing everything you can to push forward, even when you’re feeling completely drained, which speaks to how committed and resilient you are. But constantly running on empty can make everything feel even harder over time. What do you think it might take to feel a little less weighed down or to find some space for yourself?

I don’t even know, honestly. I feel so stuck that I can’t even picture what that would look like. Maybe if things weren’t so tense with my wife or if we could figure out how to help my son… but right now, it all feels so far out of reach.

It sounds like the tension at home and concern for your son are at the heart of a lot of what you’re feeling, and it may be hard to imagine things improving when you’re feeling stuck and overwhelmed. Recognizing those key challenges is a step, though—it shows how deeply you want things to get better for your family. What do you think would need to change for you to feel some hope again?

It’s hard to say. I guess if my wife and I could get back on the same page and figure out how to support our son, maybe things would feel less out of control. I just don’t know how to even start working on that—everything feels so fragile right now, like one wrong step could make it worse.

It sounds like you’re worried about making things worse but also recognize that finding common ground with your wife and supporting your son could be really important in turning things around. That shows a lot of thoughtfulness and care in how you’re approaching this, even amidst all the uncertainty. What do you think might help you and your wife start communicating or working together in a way that feels more steady?

Maybe if we had some kind of guidance—or someone to help us figure out a plan for my son—it could take the pressure off us and help us stop fighting so much. But honestly, I’m hesitant. I don’t know if talking to someone, like another counselor or something, would even make a difference, or if it’d just be another thing that doesn’t help.

It sounds like the idea of seeking guidance has crossed your mind, but you're feeling unsure about whether it would actually make a difference. That uncertainty makes sense, especially if past efforts haven't felt helpful. At the same time, it seems like you're searching for something that could ease the pressure and bring you and your wife closer to addressing things together. What would need to happen for you to feel more confident about taking a step like that?

Maybe if I knew it would actually give us real tools to help my son or help my wife and I work better as a team, I’d feel better about it. I just don’t want to waste time or energy on something that doesn’t help us.

That’s completely understandable—you’ve already been pouring so much energy into trying to make things better, and you want to make sure that any next step would truly be worthwhile. It sounds like you’re open to the idea if it offers real, tangible support for your son and your family’s dynamic. What would be most important for you in a resource or person helping you through this?

I think I’d want someone who really understands what we’re going through and won’t just give us generic advice. Like, someone who can actually help us figure out what’s going on with my son and give us practical ways to handle it. And someone who can help my wife and me feel like we’re on the same team again.

It sounds like finding someone who can truly understand your family’s unique situation and provide meaningful, practical guidance is key for you—both in terms of supporting your son and helping your wife and you reconnect as partners. That thoughtfulness shows just how much you want this to be a step forward rather than another source of stress. Is there anything else you’d want to make sure this person could offer?
